If digesting blood is quite taxing for mosquitoes maybe there could one day be a vaccine of sorts that puts something in our blood that is safe for humans but kills any mosquitoes that try to digest it. That way a selection pressure could be placed on mosquitoes that bite giving species that don’t an advantage. If the species that specialize on humans like the anopheles mosquito die before being able to lay eggs in water we could potentially drive them to extinction with such a measure while leaving all the species that don’t bite alone meaning that the animals that eat mosquitoes as part of their diet won’t miss out from either making the ecological impact of such a targeted extinction minimal (in theory)

I worked in the lab that studied those exact mosquitos at the University of Oregon. I want to say one of the main projects being worked on was studying the changes in photoperiodism. I could be mistaken. I think we may have been studying their response to climate change too. But my memory of the specifics is fuzzy because that was back around 2006 or 2007. I had to resign earlier than I wanted to due to some personal issues, unfortunately.

Bradshaw and Holzapfel and everyone else there were amazing. The adults were fed raisins. I primarily dealt with the larvae. I, along with several others, fed them, cleaned their petri dishes and separated hatchlings into new dishes with smaller and more manageable population sizes. I want to say from one dish with a couple hundred to dishes with 25 apiece. I definitely could be off on those numbers. All I really remember is there were a ton of the wee bebes in their birth dish and they were probably about the size of this apostrophe: ' and they were white. But kind of translucent. We had magnifiers to make it easier to see them, but I found it much easier to be more accurate with my pipette with just using my unaided eyes. I was one of the lucky ones that could focus my eyes right to see the little buggers without the magnifiers.

Before I got there they had some from one of the biting populations too. The most clean way to feed the biters was with a volunteer. They tried hanging various suspended "containers" filled with blood, but since the bites wouldn't close like skin, the blood would leak out.

I'd written something about this kind of thing more than a year ago.

A stream of mosquitoes pours over your face. Haphazardly bumping into your eyelids, they tickle your nostrils with the vibration of their wings and stick their mouthparts into your rosy cheeks. Your neck is coated with mosquitoes, stretched by the pressure of fresh blood, but you don't seem to mind. You open your mouth and let them venture in. One by one, the throbbing whines drop out of the chorus and you feel new pin-pricks on the flesh of your lips and the back of your throat. You smile. You're absorbing the swarm just as they absorb you.
